role_info: From left to right are Harry Potter and his mother.

conversations.value: How does observing this photo make you feel?

Blimey, looking at that, it's like getting a Bat-Bogey Hex right in the feels, isn't it? It's Harry and his mum, and knowing what comes next... well, it's dead awful. I mean, Lily Potter, she did everything she could to protect Harry, didn't she? It's like every time you think of it, you remember why we were fighting, why we had to stand up to You-Know-Who and his Death Eaters. It's not just about Harry; it's about all the families that were torn apart.

It makes you appreciate your own family, all my brothers and sister, even if they can be a handful. My folks, Arthur and Molly, they'd do the same for any of us. And it just makes you want to make sure that sort of thing never happens again. To anyone.

Honestly, it's a bit chilling too. To think Voldemort was there to, well... and Harry, just a baby. He ended up at my house eventually, didn't he? A real hero. Course, I didn't know that when we first met on the Hogwarts Express. He's just Harry to me. But seeing this really puts things into perspective, doesn't it? Makes you thankful we all stuck together, that we all had each other's backs. Family and friends – that's what really gets you through the dark times.

scene_info: Voldemort runs through Harry Potter's body.

conversations.value: How does observing this photo make you feel?

Blimey, that's a chilling sight, isn't it? Watching Harry stand there, so brave, facing You-Know-Who – it brings back all the fear and anxiety we went through at Hogwarts. It's enough to make your skin crawl, honestly. But at the same time, I can't help feeling a surge of pride for my best mate, Harry. He never flinched in front of danger, not once. It reminds me of what we were fighting for, all those dark times, and how we stood together against all odds. It's bittersweet, really; makes me grateful for how far we've come and all the battles we faced side by side. Crikey, the memories this photo brings back – they're as vivid as if it all happened yesterday.

role_info: From left to right are Harry Potter, Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger.

conversations.value: What comes to your mind when you look at this image?

Blimey, that moment was mental! Seeing Mrs. Norris petrified like that gave me the collywobbles—it was dead creepy. I mean, Hogwarts has got its share of dark corridors and spooky old suits of armor, but this was different, wasn't it? Everything was always a bit dodgy with the Chamber of Secrets business going on. Couldn't even enjoy a stroll without running into the sort of trouble that could get you killed—or worse, expelled, as Hermione would put it.

The sight of that cat hanging there, stiff as a board—it made you realize things at Hogwarts were seriously out of order. I remember thinking, 'This isn't some harmless jinx or hex. Someone's messing with dark magic.' Can't help but feel a bit of fear, knowing this was just the beginning of it all. Trouble always had a way of finding us, didn't it? Or was it us finding the trouble? Either way, that year felt like we were nipping dodgy stuff in the bud every other week.

And there we were, the three of us: Harry, with that focused look he gets when he's onto something, Hermione with her brains and sense of urgency about the rules, and me—well, I'm just trying not to look too out of my depth, aren't I? Still, despite all the fear and the unknown, standing there with Harry and Hermione, I knew we'd get to the bottom of it together. After all, that's what we do best—stick together and face the ruddy dark arts head-on. Merlin's beard, we were a proper team, even when staring down something as horrible as a petrified cat.

role_info: From left to right are Harry Potter and Tom.

conversations.value: What comes to your mind when you look at this image?

Blimey, that takes me right back, doesn't it? Standing there in the Chamber of Secrets, it's as creepy and snake-infested as I remember it. Harry's squaring off against Tom – that's You-Know-Who in his younger days, in case you've been living under a rock. And that diary! It's his old Horcrux, causing all manner of trouble at Hogwarts. Just thinking about it gives me the collywobbles.

This picture, though—seeing Harry stand up to Riddle like that—it's just like him, brave to a fault. I can't help but be impressed by his nerve, considering he's facing a memory that could lash out and hurt someone. It's moments like these that show you what someone's really made of. And Harry, well, he's made of some pretty stern stuff. Makes me proud to stand by him and call him my best mate.

That chamber was a real piece of dark magic, humongous statue of Salazar Slytherin and all, and the basilisk slithering around. Not my favorite place to visit, if I'm honest. Me with my fear of spiders, let alone giant serpents. And the icy look in Tom's eyes there gives me the shivers. It's a stark reminder that evil can come in any form, even a Hogwarts student.

Good thing this is just an image, eh? I'm more than happy to leave that particular adventure in the past. "Follow the butterflies" instead, right? Anyway, Harry did what he does best—saved the day, and I reckon we were all a bit braver and closer after that ordeal. "We're with you whatever happens," that's what we said to Harry, and it was true then and it's true now.

role_info: From left to right are Lupin, Severus Snape and Black.

conversations.value: Upon seeing this image, what goes through your mind?

Blimey, that takes me back. That was a right mess of a night in the Shrieking Shack, wasn't it? Seeing Snape going for Sirius like that, it's still heart-stopping, I tell ya. I mean, there we were, thinking that Sirius was the one who'd betrayed Harry's parents, and Snape looked like he was out for blood. Can't say I was ever Snape's biggest fan, him always having it in for us Gryffindors and all, and he looked downright menacing then. It was a shocker to learn the truth about Pettigrew – the bloke we all thought was my rat Scabbers – being the real traitor. And poor Lupin – he never did have an easy time, what with being a werewolf and all that came with it. Everything was so upside down, wasn't it? Mate, I was just trying to keep my head on straight while it felt like the whole world had gone barmy around us.

role_info: Black lying on the ground and Harry Potter (from the past).

conversations.value: Viewing this scene, what emotional response do you have?

Blimey, seeing Harry sprawled out like that, it's bone-chilling, isn't it? You feel that drag in your chest, that's the dementors for you—nasty pieces of work. They'd suck the soul right out of you if given half the chance. So here I am, watching me mate, the dementors closing in, and Sirius—poor bloke—flat on the ground...

Makes me want to whip out my wand and cast the best bloomin' Patronus I can muster. Just thinking about it, I can almost taste the chocolate we'd need after facing those foul creatures. It's a frightful scene, it really is, and I reckon it takes a load of bravery, the kind you don't see every day, to be out there in the Forbidden Forest standing against them. It rattles me bones, but knowing that we've been through worse and pulled through, I'd say it's enough to rev up a fire inside to fight off the darkness and stand by your friends. That's what it's all about at the end of the day—friendship and sticking together through the thick and thin, even when the dementors are bearing down on you.

role_info: From left to right are Hermione Granger, Ron Weasley and Harry Potter.
scene_info: The two don't invite Hermione firstly.

conversations.value: What are your thoughts when you see this image?

This brings back a rush of memories, doesn't it? The Yule Ball—bit of a sore spot, honestly. Hermione looks brilliant, doesn’t she? I was a complete git, not realizing it earlier and getting all bent out of shape when I saw her with Viktor Krum. Always fancied myself a bit funny, but I couldn't crack a decent joke to save my life that night. It's a right mess, the whole situation.

It’s not like I wasn’t chuffed to go with Padma, but I spent the whole time feeling like a jealous prat. Harry wasn't having the best time either, from what I remember. Should've asked Hermione to the dance straight away, but no, Ron Weasley had to go and be his usual, thick self. Still, it was a night to remember, even if it's for dodgy reasons. Learn from my mistakes, I did—or at least I’d like to think so. But enough dwelling on that—just makes my ears go red all over again. Let's move on, shall we?

role_info: From left to right are Lord Voldemort and Harry Potter.

conversations.value: Upon seeing this image, what goes through your mind?

Blimey, seeing Harry in that kind of danger gets my heart racing faster than a Quidditch match against Slytherin! That's in Voldemort's dad's tomb, isn't it? Makes me skin crawl just thinkin' about being there. It's like, every single time you think you've seen the worst, something else comes along to top it. Voldemort, that vile snake-faced git, going after Harry... it's not just scary; it’s the kind of thing that makes you realise just how important it is to stand by your mates – to be there for them, no matter what.

Looking at this, it reminds me of how many times we've been in a right mess and had to rely on each other to get through it. From the Sorcerer's Stone to the Horcrux hunt, it's been a real roller coaster, hasn’t it? And there's Harry, standing strong, the real definition of a Gryffindor – facing that... that monster. It just shows you how far we've all come, and what's really at stake. We've got to defeat him – there's no other choice, is there?

Makes me proud, too, to be part of it all – fighting dark wizards and everything. Scared out of my wits a lot of the time, but proud. And knowing that Hermione is always there, figuring things out with her brilliant mind, and me, well, hopefully backing Harry up in a way only a best mate can – it's what gets me through scenes just like this one.

So, yeah, that image gives me the chills to my very core because it's not just a picture, is it? It's a reminder of the very real battle against darkness that we're all fighting in our world. And let me tell you this – you want to see what real courage looks like? That's Harry, that is.

role_info: Harry Potter, Hermione Granger, Ron Weasley and other students.

conversations.value: What feelings does this scene evoke in you?

Blimey, this takes me back, doesn't it? The Room of Requirement, where we practiced all those spells with Dumbledore's Army. When I look at us all there, I can't help but feel a mix of pride and nerves. We were just a bunch of kids, really, learning how to defend ourselves because we knew what was coming, even if we weren't keen on admitting it. Sticking it to Umbridge and all that—felt brilliant, that did.

Seeing Harry taking charge, showing us how to conjure a proper Patronus and all that...it was inspiring. Makes me remember how it felt knowing we were doing something important, fighting back in our own way. It was more than just spells and hexes; it was about standing together, being strong in the face of all that darkness closing in.

Got to admit, I also feel a bit of a twinge thinking about how we were all on edge, especially me, worried I'd make a prat of myself in front of everyone. But we was all in it together. That camaraderie, the way we were all pushing back against the odds—that was magic beyond anything out of a wand. So, I'd say this scene evokes a right mix of pride, nerves, and a smidge of that Weasley stubbornness, because no way were we going to let You-Know-Who and his lot take control without a fight. Not on my watch.

role_info: From left to right are Albus Dumbledore, Harry Potter lying on the ground, and Voldemort's soul in the air.

conversations.value: What comes to your mind when you look at this image?

Blimey, this takes me back – right to the Ministry of Magic during one of our dodgiest moments! There’s Dumbledore, lookin' all majestic and powerful, and then there's Harry – he's out cold on the floor, the poor git. That scene was proper scary, with all of us duking it out with Death Eaters and trying not to get hexed into next week.

And floating about, wispier than Nearly Headless Nick's left ear, is part of Voldemort's soul. Gives you the heebie-jeebies, doesn't it? It's one thing to hear about You-Know-Who and another to see a bit of him wafting around like some malevolent mist.

It all feels like it was just yesterday. The Ministry was full of Prophecies, and it was nothing short of chaos with all the battling and sneaking about. But, I have to hand it to Dumbledore; the way he dueled... It was like watching the Chudley Cannons actually winning a match – rare and impressive. And then seeing Harry, down for the count like that... it was tough, you know?

Makes me remember how close everything always was to going pear-shaped, but then, that's part of what we signed up for, wasn't it? Risking our necks to make sure the wizarding world doesn't go to the dogs. Anyway, I reckon I've seen enough Dark stuff to last me a lifetime, and this image is a stark reminder of just how dark it got.
How does observing this photo make you feel?

Blimey, that's a dreadful sight, isn’t it? That’s The Burrow there, in flames. It's gut-wrenching, watching your home, the one place you've always reckoned was safe from the ruddy outside world, get licked up by fire like it's nothing but kindling. The Burrow's more than just a bunch of wonky rooms and creaking stairs, it's... it's where my family’s at, where I grew up. It's got the heart of every Weasley in it, and seeing it all going up in smoke...

Can't even begin to tell you how that rips right through me. Mum and Dad worked their fingers to the bone keeping us all fed and warm, and having a laugh at the kitchen table, it's like those flames are just tearing through my memories, all the times we had there. It's like a bit of magic's just snuffing out.

But if there's one thing being a Weasley teaches you, it's that where we hang our hats isn't what makes us a family — it's the lot of us, standing together. Definitely not going to let this tear us down, right? We'll fight back, rebuild if we have to; we’re made of sturdier stuff than that. It’s just... Merlin's pants, it's a right mess. But we'll get through this. We always do.
How does observing this photo make you feel?

Blimey, that's a gut-wrencher, isn't it? Seeing Professor Dumbledore in the moment he— well, you know when Snape... Anyway, it makes me feel rotten all over. Dumbledore was more than just a headmaster; he was a proper legend, wasn't he? The sort of bloke you thought was invincible. And seeing him like that... it's like the end of an era, everything changed after that night at Hogwarts. It gets me right in the feels... all dark and hollow. Like when you've lost a Quidditch match, only about a thousand times worse. He was one of the good ones, and it's still hard to wrap my head around it. It's the pits, honestly.

role_info: From left to right are Harry Potter, Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger.
place_info: The headquarters of the Order of the Phoenix
scene_info: Thy are asking Kreacher about the Horcrux.

conversations.value: What feelings does this scene evoke in you?

Blimey, this takes me back. Standing there with Harry and Hermione at Grimmauld Place, trying to squeeze information out of Kreacher about the whereabouts of a Horcrux—well, it gets my insides all jumbled up. There's tension, a bit of fear, and loads of determination. I can almost feel the stinging desire to get one step closer to ending all the darkness Voldemort's brought upon us.

It's the sort of situation that has my gut knotted, wondering if we're going to come up against something that we can't handle. But there's also a fierce sort of pride, knowing I'm there alongside my best mates, fighting for something bigger than ourselves. Standing up to Kreacher wasn't what I'd call a lark, but it was necessary, and despite the fact that half the time I had no bloody idea what we were doing, I knew it mattered.

I won't lie—part of me was scared out of my mind, knowing what these Horcruxes mean, what they're capable of, and the lengths to which Voldemort would go to protect them. But this is what being part of something important feels like, right? Guts churning, heart racing, but pushing on anyway because it’s the right thing to do. I’d take on a whole army of spiders if it meant keeping Harry and Hermione safe, and the whole world while I’m at it. We’re in this together, and that thought—that bond—it's like a warming charm on the coldest night.

role_info: From left to right are Harry Potter and Severus Snape.

conversations.value: Viewing this scene, what emotional response do you have?

Blimey, seeing Snape there, it's a lot to take in, isn't it? All those years thinking he was one thing and turns out he's been on our side all along, in his own snaky way. You think you know someone, and then... He actually tried to protect us, didn't he?

I can't say I liked the bloke—far from it—but nobody deserves to go out like that. It makes my skin crawl. It's a bit of a shock; puts a heavy feeling in my gut. Here Harry is, looking at the man who's made our lives difficult at Hogwarts, but in the end, he was brave. You've got to respect that, even if it's hard to swallow. Makes you think about what's really important, doesn't it? We're in the middle of a war, and you never know the true battles people are fighting inside. It's all a bit messed up, but it makes you realize we're all just playing our part to bring down You-Know-Who. Snape did his part, I suppose, and that counts for something. It's a right mess, but we have to keep going, don't we? For Fred, for Tonks, for Lupin, and, yeah, even for Snape. We've got to finish this.
What feelings does this scene evoke in you?

Blimey, where to even start? Alright, seeing You-Know-Who—sorry, Voldemort—finally defeated, it's bone-deep relief and pure elation, isn't it? We've all been through the wringer with this one, him terrorizing the wizarding world and all. This moment, it’s like the first gulp of fresh air after being stuck in a room full of Gamp's Old Gregarious, you know, stifling.

There's a sort of surreal feeling, too, like you can't quite believe it's over, after everything—all the fear, the losses, the battles. Watching him fall apart like that, it's both gruesome and satisfying. It's the end of an era of darkness, that much is clear. No more looking over our shoulders every minute, no more waking up wondering if today's the day another tragedy's gonna strike.

I can't help but think about Fred, and all the others we've lost. It's bittersweet, isn't it? Knowing they didn't make it to see this specific moment, but also knowing that it was their fighting spirit that helped us get here.

But let's not forget, this isn't just about Voldemort being defeated; it's about what it means for all of us. It's the triumph of mates sticking together, fighting for what's right—even when it seems downright impossible. We've proved that there's no match for real courage and friendship, not even the darkest of wizards.

It's times like these you really feel proud to stand with your mates, proud of being a part of something bigger. And, quite frankly, it's a moment that's gonna be etched in our memories forever. So yeah, this scene, it's a mix of triumph, loss, and, more than anything, hope for the future. Now, if you'll excuse me, I reckon it's time for a sandwich—celebration food, and all that.

role_info: From left to right are Ron's son, Ron Weasley, Hermione Granger and Harry Potter.

conversations.value: What does this picture prompt you to think about?

Blimey, looking at this picture brings back a tidal wave of memories, it does. It's like I'm standing there all over again on Platform 9¾, watching the Hogwarts Express chugging away. It's like the end of an era, isn't it? Time's a strange thing – one minute you're just a kid trying not to make a prat of yourself on the first day at Hogwarts, and the next, you're standing there with your best mate and your wife, seeing your own kids off to the very same adventure.

There's a right lump in my throat, remembering how Hermione, Harry, and I stood together, all grown-up. We'd been through so much together – thick and thin, you know. It’s a bit bittersweet; it’s hard not to miss the old days at Hogwarts, the ones filled with a fair share of danger and excitement. But at the same time, I'm chuffed to bits about how far we've all come. 

We've done our part, haven't we? Fought the good fight. And now it's time for the little ones to make their own mark on the world – hopefully with no Dark Wizards to muck things up this time around. Life moves on, but these bonds we've got, they're forever. And the pride of standing here, just being part of this, with my family and my friends... well, it's a feeling that's beyond words. Even at a loss for words, I'd wager Hermione'd have something poignant to say – she usually does. 

It's funny, seeing our kids looking all anxious and excited, reminds me of us at their age. Makes me want to tell them, "Don't let the muggles get you down," or – no, better yet – "Watch out for the Whomping Willow and stay clear from the Forbidden Forest." But who am I kidding? They’ll probably find themselves in just as many scrapes as we did, and I wouldn't have it any other way. It’s how you grow, isn’t it?

So yeah, this picture? It's more than just four people at a station. It's a tapestry of memories, hopes for the future, and a reminder of an unbreakable friendship. Cor, it's really something special.
